content:
'''Welcome!''' Hello, and [[Wikipedia:Introduction|welcome]] to Wikipedia! Thank you for [[Special:Contributions/81.70.239.244|your contributions]]. I hope you like the place and decide to stay. Here are some pages you might like to see: * [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] * [[Help:Contents|Help pages]] * [[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] * [[Wikipedia:How to edit a page|How to edit a page]] and [[Wikipedia:Article development|How to develop articles]] * [[Wikipedia:Your first article|How to create your first article]] (using the [[Wikipedia:Article wizard2.0|Article Wizard]] if you wish) * [[Wikipedia:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] You are welcome to continue editing articles without [[Special:Userlogin|logging in]], but many editors recommend that you '''[{{fullurl:Special:Userlogin|type=signup}} create an account]'''. Doing so is free, requires no personal information, and provides several benefits such as the ability to create articles. For a full outline and explanation of the benefits that come with creating an account, please see [[Wikipedia:Why create an account?|this page]]. If you edit without a username, your [[IP address]] (81.70.239.244) is used to identify you instead. In any case, I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Signatures|sign your comments]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your IP address (or username if you're logged in) and the date. If you need help, check out [[Wikipedia:Questions]], ask me on [[User talk:XLinkBot|my talk page]], or ask your question and then place {{[[:Category:Wikipedians looking for help|helpme]]}} before the question on this page. Again, welcome! --[[User:XLinkBot|XLinkBot]] ([[User talk:XLinkBot|talk]]) 22:36, 30 June 2010 (UTC) == June 2010 == Welcome to Wikipedia. Although everyone is welcome to contribute constructively to the encyclopedia, your addition of one or more external links to the page [[:Fadel Soliman]] has been reverted.
Your edit [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?diff=371100676&oldid=369426216 here] was reverted by an automated bot that attempts to remove links which are discouraged per our [[WP:EL|external links guideline]] from Wikipedia. The external link you added or changed is on my list of links to remove and probably shouldn't be included in Wikipedia. I removed the following link(s): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JE2Z5vBmbSI. If the external link you inserted or changed was to a [[Wikipedia:Media|media]] file (e.g. a [[Wikipedia:Media help|sound or video]] file) on an external server, then note that linking to such files may be subject to Wikipedia's [[WP:COPYRIGHT|copyright policy]] and therefore probably should not be linked to. Please consider using our [[Wikipedia:Upload|upload]] facility to upload a suitable media file.
If you were trying to insert an [[Wikipedia:External links|external link]] that does comply with our [[Wikipedia:List of policies|policies]] and [[Wikipedia:List of guidelines|guidelines]], then please accept my creator's apologies and feel free to [[WP:UNDO|undo]] the bot's revert. However, if the link does not comply with our policies and guidelines, but your edit included other, constructive, changes to the article, feel free to make those changes again without re-adding the link. Please read Wikipedia's [[WP:EL|external links guideline]] for more information, and consult my [[User:XLinkBot/Reversion reasons|list of frequently-reverted sites]]. For more information about me, see [[User:XLinkBot/FAQ|my FAQ page]]. Thanks! --[[User:XLinkBot|XLinkBot]] ([[User talk:XLinkBot|talk]]) 22:36, 30 June 2010 (UTC)
If this is a shared [[IP address]], and you didn't make the edit, please ignore this notice.

title: User talk:AnniLove
content: '''Welcome!''' Hello, {{BASEPAGENAME}}, and [[Wikipedia:Introduction|welcome]] to Wikipedia! Thank you for [[Special:Contributions/{{BASEPAGENAME}}|your contributions]]{{#if:|, especially what you did for [[:{{{art}}}]]}}. I hope you like the place and decide to stay. Here are some pages that you might find helpful: *[[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] *[[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] *[[Wikipedia:How to edit a page|How to edit a page]] *[[Wikipedia:Article development|How to write a great article]] *[[Wikipedia:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Signatures|sign]] your messages on [[Wikipedia:talk page|discussion page]]s using four [[tilde]]s (~~~~); this will automatically insert your username and the date. If you need help, check out [[Wikipedia:Questions]], ask me on {{#if:|[[user talk:{{{1}}}|my talk page]]|my talk page}}, or ask your question on this page and then place {{helpme}} before the question. Again, welcome! \ [[User:Backslash Forwardslash|Backslash Forwardslash]] / {[[User Talk: Backslash Forwardslash|talk]]} 22:01, 16 July 2009 (UTC) ==Personal Information on your Userpage== Hi {{SUBPAGENAME}}. My name is Backslash Forwardslash. I am a Wikipedia administrator, and I noticed you have recently created a userpage. I don't intend to scare you away or attempt to intimidate you, but I thought you might want to reconsider some of the items on your userpage. You may have not realised that the items on your userpage release [[Personally identifiable information|personal information]] about yourself (real name or age etc), which could be used against you in the future. While 99% of all the editors on Wikipedia are friendly, welcoming and harmless, there is a chance your personal information could be misused by editors not so 'high-minded'. A handful of editors have even felt [[Wikipedia:Harassment#Off-wiki_harassment|real-world implications]] due to their Wikipedia edits and release of personal information. Protecting [[Internet privacy|your privacy]], and remaining anonymous while on the internet — on any site — is a good idea. The internet is a worldwide and largely unregulated medium, and while Wikipedia is one of the safer sites, there are definite risks while online. With [[cyber-bullying]] and [[cyberstalking]] becoming increasingly commonplace, it is important that you take every precaution to remain [[Digital safety|safe]]. I have deleted some revisions of your userpage in respect to your privacy for the time being, just in case you wish to reverse on your decision to have such content on public display. As a result, the information is only available to [[WP:ADMIN|administrators]]. You are, of course, welcome to ask myself or another administrator to restore them, but I just wanted to make you aware of the risks involved with releasing personal information on such a public forum. If you wish to have the personal information removed so that even administrators cannot view it, I can request [[WP:OVERSIGHT|oversight]] on your behalf. You are also welcome to discuss this with me on [[User Talk:Backslash Forwardslash|my talk page]], or privately via [[Special:EmailUser/Backslash Forwardslash|e-mail]] if you have any concerns. Again, I do not want to scare you. Wikipedia is a fantastic place with an incredibly supportive community. I'm just trying to ensure you are fully aware of the risks involved in editing, which are very similar to the risks you come across every day online. Hope to hear from you. \ [[User:Backslash Forwardslash|Backslash Forwardslash]] / {[[User Talk: Backslash Forwardslash|talk]]} 22:01, 16 July 2009 (UTC)

title: User talk:180.216.89.117
content:
== Welcome to Wikipedia! == Hello, and [[Wikipedia:Introduction|welcome]] to Wikipedia! Thank you for [[Special:Contributions/180.216.89.117|your contributions]]. I hope you like the place and decide to stay. Here are some pages you might like to see: * [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] * [[Wikipedia:Contributing to Wikipedia|Contributing to Wikipedia]] * [[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] * [[Wikipedia:How to edit a page|How to edit a page]] and [[Wikipedia:Article development|How to develop articles]] * [[Wikipedia:Simplified Manual of Style|Simplified Manual of Style]] * [[Help:Wikipedia: The Missing Manual/Introduction|Intuitive guide to Wikipedia]] You are welcome to continue editing without [[Special:Userlogin|logging in]], but you may want to consider '''[{{fullurl:Special:Userlogin|type=signup&campaign=anonwelcometemplate}} creating an account]'''. Doing so is free, requires no personal information, and provides several benefits such as the ability to create articles. For a full outline and explanation of the benefits that come with creating an account, please see [[Wikipedia:Why create an account?|this page]]. If you edit without a username, your [[IP address]] (180.216.89.117) is used to identify you instead. In any case, I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Signatures|sign your comments]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your IP address (or username if you're logged in) and the date. If you need help, check out [[Wikipedia:Questions]], ask me on [[User talk:BracketBot|my talk page]], or ask your question and then place {{[[:Category:Wikipedians looking for help|helpme]]}} before the question on this page. Again, welcome! '''Vincent Marchetti''' (born 4 July 1997) is a French professional [[association football|footballer]] who currently plays for [[AC Ajaccio]] as a defender. A product of the club's youth system, he made his senior debut on 31 July 2015, coming on as a substitute for [[Riad Nouri]] in the 0–0 draw with [[Dijon FCO]] at the [[Stade François Coty]].

title: Irwin Rosenhouse
content:
{{Underlinked|date=March 2016}}

'''Irwin J. Rosenhouse''' (1924-2002) was an American visual artist based in [[New York City]].

==Early life and education==
Rosenhouse was born in Chicago in 1924. He served in the US Merchant Marine and later earned his BFA at the Cooper Union.<ref>[http://cooper.edu/giving/supporters/donor-report/2010-donor-report/iho-imo "In Honor of/In Memory of"]. Cooper Union.</ref>

==Career==

Rosenhouse's early career included work as a designer at the Museum of Modern Art<ref name="N.Y.)1967">{{cite book|author=Museum of Modern Art (New York, N.Y.)|title=Bulletin|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=d-gwAQAAIAAJ|year=1967}}</ref> and created illustrations for several publishing houses <ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/title/coffee-house-songbook/oclc/317671391 "The coffee house songbook."]. ''World Cat''.</ref><ref name=pw>{{cite book|title=The Publishers Weekly, Volume 160 No. 9|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=6qoXAAAAMAAJ|year=1966|publisher=F. Leypoldt}} page 58</ref> and for Folkways Records,<ref>[http://www.folkways.si.edu/magazine-spring-summer-2012-look-listen-cover-art-folkways-records/music/article/smithsonian "The Look of the Listen: The Cover Art of Folkways Records"]. ''Folkways Magazine''.</ref>

He also taught at Pratt Graphic Center, Brooklyn College, and New York City Technical College.

Rosenhouse illustrated a number of children's books<ref>{{cite book|title=Young Children|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=RKQrAAAAMAAJ|year=1967|publisher=National Association for the Education of Young Children}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Book Buyer's Guide|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lvdPAAAAIAAJ|year=1967}}</ref> including ''What Kind of Feet Does a Bear Have?'',<ref name="Mahony1963">{{cite book|author=Bertha E. Mahony|title=The Horn Book Magazine|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=VMg8AQAAIAAJ|year=1963|publisher=Bookshop for Boys and Girls}}</ref> ''Have You Seen Trees?''<ref>{{cite book|title=The New York Times Book Review|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=bl8hAQAAMAAJ|date=April 1967|publisher=New York Times Company}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Science Books|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pGS4AAAAIAAJ|year=1967|publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Science Education|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wsMvAQAAIAAJ|year=1969|publisher=W.G. Whitman|page=179}}</ref> and ''The Science Book of Magnets''.  He also illustrated ''The Coffee House Song Book''.<ref name=pw />

He also created woodcuts for religious and history books,<ref name="Chamberlin1991">{{cite book|author=William J. Chamberlin|title=Catalogue of English Bible Translations: A Classified Bibliography of Versions and Editions Including Books, Parts, and Old and New Testament Apocrypha and Apocryphal Books|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=tr9jk8ew8wUC&pg=PA182|date=1 January 1991|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-28041-2|pages=182–}}</ref> posters for The Arab-Israeli Peace Conference: The Road to Peace, 1989, and various record album  covers<ref name="Inc.1964">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=LiAEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA6|date=26 December 1964|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=6–|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> for Folkways Records,<ref name="GuignéResearch2008">{{cite book|author1=Anna Kearney Guigné|author2=Memorial University of Newfoundland. Institute of Social and Economic Research|title=Folksongs and folk revival: the cultural politics of Kenneth Peacock's Songs of the Newfoundland outports|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ulsSAQAAIAAJ|year=2008|publisher=ISER, Institute of Social and Economic Research|isbn=978-1-894725-06-4}}</ref><ref>[http://www.artspace.org.nz/exhibitions/2007/ronaldclyne.asp "Ronald Clyne: Folkways Records Cover Design"]. ''Artspace''.</ref> MGM Records, Columbia Records.<ref>[http://www.newspapers.com/newspage/40983340/ "Sexy, Sensational Cover"]. December 7, 1960 The Progress-Index from Petersburg, Virginia</ref>

Rosenhouse's works have been shown at the Library of Congress, The Museum of Modern Art, The Brooklyn Museum,<ref>[http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/exhibitions/796/community/posse/community/posse/ "Exhibitions: National Print Exhibition, 11th Biennial"]. Brooklyn Museum.</ref> and the San Francisco Museum of Art.  Additionally, his work is in permanent collections of<!-- the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]],--> the [[Smithsonian Institution]].<ref>[http://collections.si.edu/search/results.htm?q=rosenhouse%2C+irwin Rosenhouse, Irwin"]. Collection database at the Smithsonian Institution</ref><!--The [[Cooper Union]] Museum, and the [[New York Public Library]] Print Collection--><ref>[http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Rome%20NY%20Daily%20Sentinel/Rome%20NY%20Daily%20Sentinel%201965/Rome%20NY%20Daily%20Sentinel%201965%20-%200070.pdf "Library Displaying Rosenhouse's Works"]. ''Daily Sentinel'', Rome, NY, 4 November 1965.</ref>

Rosenhouse was the proprietor of the Rosenhouse Gallery in New York.<ref name="Company1964">{{cite book|author=Johnson Publishing Company|work=Jet|title=New York Beat|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_cEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA63|date=5 March 1964|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|pages=63–|issn=0021-5996}}</ref>

Awards include the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation Award, two-time recipient of the Huntington-Hartford fellowship,<ref>[http://www.newspapers.com/newspage/44848918/(article about the dissolution of the Huntington Hatrtford artist colony) ] ''Pottstown  Mercury '', Pottstown, Pennsylvania · July 2, 1965 Page 17.</ref> Billboard Annual Award and 1st Prize in the Rome Collaborative.

Rosenhouse resided in Nassau County, New York.

An award is given in his name by the Society of American Graphic Artists.<ref>[http://www.sagaprints.org/media/SAGAzineFall2009.pdf "SAGA members exhibit"]. ''SAGAzine''.</ref><ref>[http://hilo.hawaii.edu/news/kalono/documents/kalono_jan09.pdf "Hats off"]. ''Ka Lono Kanakahi'', Volume 24 No. 5.</ref>

== References ==

*  Poster:  Irwin Rosenhouse: The Humanist Image, Paintings and Graphics, Toronto, Tungston Galleries, 1966.
*  Marquis Who's Who: Irwin J Rosenhouse

title: 1846 in Scotland
content:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}}
{{Use British English|date=January 2016}}
{{Year in Scotland| 1846 }}
Events from the year '''1846 in [[Scotland]]'''.

== Incumbents ==
* [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Monarch]] — [[Queen Victoria]]

=== Law officers ===
* [[Lord Advocate]] — [[Duncan McNeill, 1st Baron Colonsay|Duncan McNeill]] until July; then [[Andrew Rutherfurd, Lord Rutherfurd|Andrew Rutherfurd]]
* [[Solicitor General for Scotland]] — [[Adam Anderson, Lord Anderson|Adam Anderson]]; then [[Thomas Maitland, Lord Dundrennan|Thomas Maitland]]

=== Judiciary ===
* [[Lord President of the Court of Session]] and [[Lord Justice General]] — [[David Boyle, Lord Boyle|Lord Boyle]]
* [[Lord Justice Clerk]] — [[John Hope, Lord Hope|Lord Hope]]

== Events ==
* [[22 June]] — The [[North British Railway]] is opened to public traffic between [[Edinburgh]] and [[Berwick-upon-Tweed]], the first line to cross the border between [[Scotland]] and England. [[Edinburgh Waverley railway station]] is opened.<ref>{{cite book|last=Thomas|first=John|authorlink=John Thomas (author)|title=The North British Railway, vol. 1|year=1969|publisher=David & Charles|location=Newton Abbot|isbn=0-7153-4697-0}}</ref>
* [[15 August]] — Inauguration of [[Scott Monument]] in [[Edinburgh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aboutbritain.com/ScottMonument.htm|title=Scott Monument|work=AboutBritain|accessdate=2010-11-13|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031080348/http://www.aboutbritain.com/ScottMonument.htm|archivedate=2 May 2013<!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref>
* [[21 December]] — Scottish-born surgeon [[Robert Liston]] carries out the first operation under anesthesia in Europe, at [[University College Hospital]] in [[London]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Penguin Pocket On This Day|publisher=Penguin Reference Library|isbn=0-14-102715-0|year=2006}}</ref>
* Start of [[Highland Potato Famine]].
* English tourism pioneer [[Thomas Cook]] brings 350 people from [[Leicester]] on a tour of Scotland.<ref name=NCSH>{{cite web|title=Nineteenth Century Scottish History Timeline|url=http://www.scotland.org.uk/history/nineteenth-century|work=Nineteenth Century Scotland History|publisher=Travel Scotland|accessdate=2014-04-03}}</ref>
* Lighthouses at [[Covesea Skerries Lighthouse|Covesea Skerries]], [[Chanonry Point]] and [[Cromarty]] (all designed by [[Alan Stevenson]]) first illuminated.
* [[New College, Edinburgh]], opens its doors as a theological training college for the [[Free Church of Scotland (1843–1900)|Free Church of Scotland]].
* [[Catherine Murray, Countess of Dunmore]], commissions "the Paisley Sisters" of Strond on [[Harris, Scotland|Harris]] to weave [[Tweed (cloth)|tweed]] in the [[Clan Murray]] [[tartan]], origin of the commercial [[Harris Tweed]] industry.
* Engineer [[Robert William Thomson]] is granted his first [[patent]] for a [[pneumatic tyre]], in France.
* The [[Dewar's]] [[Scotch whisky]] brand is created by [[John Dewar, Sr.]]
* [[Charles William George St John]]'s ''Short Sketches of the Wild Sports and Natural History of the Highlands'' is published.

== Births ==
* [[1 January]] — [[Edward Pinnington]], art historian, biographer and journalist (died [[1921 in Scotland|1921]])
* [[10 February]] — [[James Burns (shipowner)|James Burns]], shipowner (died [[1923 in Australia]])
* [[28 February]] — [[John F. McIntosh]], steam locomotive engineer (died [[1918 in Scotland|1918]])
* [[21 June]] — [[Marion Adams-Acton]] ("Jeanie Hering"), born Marion Jean Hamilton, novelist (died 1928 in London)

== Deaths ==
* [[12 February]] — [[Henry Duncan (minister)|Henry Duncan]], minister, geologist and social reformer (born [[1774 in Scotland|1774]])
* [[23 May]] — [[Charles Ewart]], soldier (born [[1769 in Scotland|1769]])
* Andrew Innes, last survivor of the [[Buchanites]]

== The Arts ==
* [[William Motherwell]]'s ''Poetical Works'' are published posthumously.

== See also ==
{{Portal|Scotland}}
* [[Timeline of Scottish history]]
* [[1846 in the United Kingdom]]

== References ==

title: User talk:Delene1985
content:
;Welcome! Hello and [[Wikipedia:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]] to [[Wikipedia]]. Thank you for [[Special:Contributions/Delene1985|your contributions]]. I hope you like the place and decide to stay. The following links will help you begin editing on Wikipedia: *[[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] *[[Wikipedia:How to edit a page|How to edit a page]] *[[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Editing tutorial]] *[[Wikipedia:Picture tutorial|Picture tutorial]] *[[Wikipedia:How to write a great article|How to write a great article]] *[[Wikipedia:Naming conventions|Naming conventions]] *[[Wikipedia:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] ;Please bear these points in mind while editing Wikipedia: * [[Wikipedia:Copyrights|Respect copyrights]] – do not copy and paste text or images directly from other websites. * Maintain a [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view|neutral point of view]] – this is one of Wikipedia's core policies. * Take particular care while adding biographical material about a [[Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons|living person]] to any Wikipedia page and follow [[Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons|Wikipedia's Biography of Living Persons policy]]. Particularly, controversial and negative statements should be [[Wikipedia:Citing sources|referenced]] with multiple [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable sources]]. * No [[Wikipedia:Edit warring|edit warring]] or [[Wikipedia:Sock puppetry|sock puppetry]]. * If you are testing, please use the [[Wikipedia:Sandbox|Sandbox]] to [{{fullurl:Wikipedia:Sandbox|action=edit}} do so]. * Do not add troublesome content to any [[Wikipedia:What is an article|article]], such as: [[copyright]]ed text, [[Wikipedia:Libel|libel]], advertising or promotional messages, and text that is not related to an article's subject. Deliberately adding such content or otherwise editing articles maliciously is considered [[Wikipedia:Vandalism|vandalism]]; doing so will result in your account or IP being [[WP:BLOCK|blocked from editing]]. * Do not use talk pages as discussion or forum pages as Wikipedia is [[WP:NOT#FORUM|not a forum]]. The [[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Wikipedia tutorial]] is a good place to start learning about Wikipedia. If you have any questions, see the [[Wikipedia:Help|help pages]], add a question to the [[Wikipedia:village pump|village pump]] or ask me on my talk page. By the way, you can sign your name on Talk and discussion pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~ (the software will replace them with your signature and the date). Again, welcome!{{z129}} == June 2014 == [[File:Information orange.svg|25px|alt=Information icon]] Please do not add promotional material to Wikipedia. While [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view|objective prose]] about beliefs, products or services ''is'' acceptable, Wikipedia is not intended to be [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a soapbox|a vehicle for soapboxing, advertising or promotion]]. ''I have deleted your sandbox for his reason.''[[Category:User talk pages with Uw-advert2 notices|{{PAGENAME}}]]  —[[User:Smalljim|SMALL]][[User talk:Smalljim#top|JIM]]  21:05, 3 June 2014 (UTC) SMALLJIM - Apologies I was under the impression that I was on a test page. title: Talk:New Flyer
content:
{{WPBUS|class=start}} == Models == While the article's tone appears quite professional compared to what I found in [[Millennium Transit Services#Models]], the models listing looked like a jigsaw of dashes and parentheses. I did some cleaning up in '''Historical''' and '''Current''' subsections, just to make dash use in there consistent and user-friendly in terms of legibility. Most of this is a good part from my own point of view and a good part from the [[Dash]] article. *I didn't touch on bus models, as they use the hyphen-minus anyway; *Years in the form of "from xxxx ''to'' xxxx" and "xxxx ''to'' present" look like this: 1968–1974 and "1996–present"; *Years in the form of "from late 1980s ''to'' mid 1990s" are given an unspaced em dash: "late 1980s—mid 1990s", since the ''from'' and ''to'' statements are not mere numbers, but contain two (or more) word constructs (I don't mind if someone disputes this statement in favour of an en dash); *Parenthetical statements, such as "F40LF — Fuel Cell (Hydrogen) Test Buses (1996)" are separated with a spaced em dash. While indeed in [[American English]] usage, spaced em dashes are not used, I still feel it is warranted in here, so as to separate bus model numbers from the rest of the text and not make it appear as part of the model number itself; *For consistency in sections with the above point, parenthetical statements are also separated with a spaced em dash. Despite my own cleanups, there is still an overabundance of parentheses.
-[[User:Mardus|Mardus]] 01:05, 22 October 2006 (UTC) This has been eliminated, with all models now in a table, as the [[Motor Coach Industries]] article has it, with both US and metric units given.--[[User:AEMoreira042281|AEMoreira042281]] ([[User talk:AEMoreira042281|talk]]) 15:52, 19 January 2008 (UTC) == Removed client list == I've removed the client list from the article on the basis that it doesn't add anything to the article. It can be easily summed up as "Yeah, they've had a lot of customers." My thought is that if the client is notable in relation to the topic then fine (like the 870 frame fiasco for [[Flxible]]). Otherwise, it's not particularly notable and makes the article unnecessarily long. [[User:SchuminWeb|SchuminWeb]] ([[User talk:SchuminWeb|Talk]]) 10:45, 3 July 2007 (UTC) == Invero == Who ever said that OC Transpo owns the DE40i is wrong, I should know, I live in Ottawa. So I fixed it. [[Special:Contributions/99.245.254.34|99.245.254.34]] ([[User talk:99.245.254.34|talk]]) 01:58, 2 September 2008 (UTC) ==File:New Flyer XN60.jpg Nominated for speedy Deletion== {| |- | [[File:Image-x-generic.svg|100px]] | An image used in this article, [[commons:File:New Flyer XN60.jpg|File:New Flyer XN60.jpg]], has been nominated for speedy deletion at [[Wikimedia Commons]] for the following reason: ''Copyright violations'' ;What should I do? ''Don't panic''; deletions can take a little longer at Commons than they do on Wikipedia. This gives you an opportunity to contest the deletion (although please review Commons guidelines before doing so). The best way to contest this form of deletion is by posting on the image talk page. * If the image is [[WP:NFCC|non-free]] then you may need to upload it to Wikipedia (Commons does not allow fair use) * If the image isn't freely licensed and there is no [[WP:FUR|fair use rationale]] then it cannot be uploaded or used. * If the image has already been deleted you may want to try [[commons:COM:UR|Commons Undeletion Request]] To take part in any discussion, or to review a more detailed deletion rationale please visit the relevant [[commons:File:New Flyer XN60.jpg|image page (File:New Flyer XN60.jpg)]] ''This is Bot placed notification, another user has nominated/tagged the image'' --[[User:CommonsNotificationBot|CommonsNotificationBot]] ([[User talk:CommonsNotificationBot|talk]]) 10:34, 27 February 2012 (UTC) |} ==File:TheBus (Honolulu) New Flyer DE60LF Route A 132.JPG Nominated for speedy Deletion== {| |- | [[File:Image-x-generic.svg|100px]] | An image used in this article, [[commons:File:TheBus (Honolulu) New Flyer DE60LF Route A 132.JPG|File:TheBus (Honolulu) New Flyer DE60LF Route A 132.JPG]], has been nominated for speedy deletion at [[Wikimedia Commons]] for the following reason: ''Copyright violations'' ;What should I do? title: Arthur Witteveen
content:
{{orphan|date=January 2012}}
'''Arthur Witteveen''' (born 19??) is a Dutch judge and legal writer. He is the First Secretary of the [[International Court of Justice]] in [[The Hague]].<ref>[http://www.icj-cij.org/presscom/index.php?pr=99&pt=1&p1=6&p2=1&PHPSESSID=5c407 www.icj-cij.org]</ref> In April 1996 he published a book on ''The International Court of Justice 1946-1996'' with [[Arthur Eyffinger]].

title: May 1896 tornado outbreak sequence
content:
[[Image:Damage at Seventh and Rutger.jpg|thumb|250px|Damage from the [[St. Louis-East St. Louis Tornado]].]]
The '''May 1896 tornado outbreak sequence''' was a series of violent and deadly [[tornado outbreak]]s that struck much of the [[Central United States|Central]] and [[Southern United States]] from May 15 to May 28, 1896. It is considered one of the worst [[tornado outbreak sequence]]s on record with tornado expert [[Thomas P. Grazulis|Tom Grazulis]] stating that the week of May 24–28 was "perhaps the most violent single week of tornado activity in US history".<ref name="Tornado Project">{{cite web |last=Grazulis |first=Tom |authorlink=Thomas P. Grazulis |author2=Doris Grazulis |title=1896 Tornadoes |publisher=The Tornado Project |url=http://tornadoproject.com/past/pastts95.htm#1896 |accessdate=2014-06-22 |archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20140226141138/http://tornadoproject.com/past/pastts95.htm |archivedate = 2014-02-26 }}</ref> There were four particularly notable [[tornado]] outbreaks during the two-week period. It produced three [[List of F5 and EF5 tornadoes|F5 tornadoes]] as well as the third deadliest tornado ever in [[United States]] history. A total of 484 people were killed during the entire outbreak sequence by at least 38 different tornadoes which struck [[Texas]], [[Oklahoma]], [[Kansas]], [[Nebraska]], [[Illinois]], [[Missouri]], [[Iowa]], [[Kentucky]], and [[Michigan]].{{#tag:ref|An [[tornado outbreak|outbreak]] is generally defined as a group of at least six tornadoes (the number sometimes varies slightly according to local climatology) with no more than a six-hour gap between individual tornadoes. An [[tornado outbreak sequence|outbreak sequence]], prior to (after) modern records that began in 1950, is defined as, at most, two (one) consecutive days without at least one [[Fujita scale#Rating classifications|significant]] (F2 or stronger) tornado.<ref name=OutbreakClimo>{{cite web|last=Schneider|first=Russell S.|title=Tornado Outbreak Day Sequences: Historic Events and Climatology (1875-2003)|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/publications/schneider/otbrkseq.pdf|publisher=[[Storm Prediction Center]]|accessdate=13 February 2013|author2=Harold E. Brooks |author3=Joseph T. Schaefer |location=[[Norman, Oklahoma]]}}</ref>|group="nb"}}{{#tag:ref|All damage totals are in 1896 [[United States dollar]]s unless otherwise noted.|group="nb"}}

==Confirmed tornadoes==
{{Tornado Chart | Total=38+ | F0=? | F1=? | F2=17 | F3=12 | F4=6 | F5=3}}
{{clear}}

===May 15 event===
{| class="wikitable toccolours collapsible" style="width:100%;"
!colspan="6"|List of confirmed tornadoes - May 15, 1896
|-
|'''<center>[[Fujita scale|F#]]'''</center> || <center>'''Location'''</center> || <center>'''County'''</center> || <center>'''Time (UTC)'''</center> || <center>'''Path length'''</center> || <center>'''Damage'''</center>
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Texas]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''SW of [[Justin, Texas|Justin]] to E of [[Ponder, Texas|Ponder]]'''
|[[Denton County, Texas|Denton]]
|2015
|{{convert|13|mi|km|}}
|'''2 deaths''' — 22 homes were damaged in Justin, with five destroyed, and two swept away. Every business in town received some degree of damage. 25 injuries occurred, 17 of which were serious.<ref name=Grazulis1>Grazulis, ''Significant'', p. 674</ref>
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''W of [[Denton, Texas|Denton]]'''
|[[Denton County, Texas|Denton]], [[Cooke County, Texas|Cooke]]
|2045
|{{convert|17|mi|km|}}
|'''3 deaths''' — Struck the town of [[Gribble Springs (ghost town), Texas|Gribble Springs]], where seven houses were destroyed and three people were killed. Two homes and numerous barns were also destroyed in Cooke County.<ref name=Grazulis1 />
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat5}} | <big>'''F5'''</big>
|'''E of [[Pilot Point, Texas|Pilot Point]] to [[Sherman, Texas|Sherman]]'''
|[[Denton County, Texas|Denton]], [[Grayson County, Texas|Grayson]]
|2230
|{{convert|28|mi|km|}}
|'''73 deaths''' — ''[[May 1896 tornado outbreak sequence#Sherman, Texas|See section on this tornado]]'' — One of the most intense tornadoes of the 19th century.<ref name=Grazulis1 />
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''SE of [[Sherman, Texas|Sherman]] to SE of [[Hendrix, Oklahoma|Hendrix, OK]]'''
|[[Grayson County, Texas|Grayson]], [[Bryan County, Oklahoma|Bryan]](OK)
|2245
|{{convert|18|mi|km|}}
|Tornado formed after the Sherman tornado lifted. 20 homes were damaged along the Choctaw Creek (then called Choctaw Bayou). A trading post was destroyed as well. 35 injuries occurred, at least 20 of which were serious.<ref name=Grazulis1 /> 
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Oklahoma]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''[[Blue, Oklahoma|Blue]] area'''
|[[Bryan County, Oklahoma|Bryan]]
|2330
|unknown
|'''4 deaths''' — A family of four was killed in their home.<ref name=Grazulis1 /> 
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Kansas]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''NE of [[Moundridge, Kansas|Moundridge]]'''
|[[McPherson County, Kansas|McPherson]]
|1000
|unknown
|'''1 death''' — Brief, early-morning touchdown leveled a house. An elderly man was killed and his wife was injured.<ref name=Grazulis1 /> 
|-
|colspan="7"|<small>Sources: Grazulis (1993)<ref name=Grazulis1 /></small>
|}
{{clear}}

===May 17 event===
{| class="wikitable toccolours collapsible" style="width:100%;"
!colspan="6"|List of confirmed tornadoes - May 17, 1896

|'''<center>[[Fujita scale|F#]]'''</center> || <center>'''Location'''</center> || <center>'''County'''</center> || <center>'''Time (UTC)'''</center> || <center>'''Path length'''</center> || <center>'''Damage'''</center>

|0645

|'''5 deaths''' — South of [[Elva (ghost town), Kentucky|Elva]], a small two-room home was obliterated, killing a family of five.<ref name=Grazulis1 />

|2300
|{{convert|100|mi|km|}}
|'''25 deaths''' — ''[[May 1896 tornado outbreak sequence#Seneca/Oneida, Kansas/Falls City, Nebraska|See section on this tornado]]'' — Was more than {{convert|2|mi|km|}} wide.<ref name=Grazulis1 />
|-
|colspan="7"|<small>Sources: Grazulis (1993)<ref name=Grazulis1 /></small>
|}

|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat4}} | <big>'''F4'''</big>
|'''SW of [[Polk City, Iowa|Polk City]] to [[Mingo, Iowa|Mingo]]'''
|[[Polk County, Iowa|Polk]], [[Jasper County, Iowa|Jasper]]
|0430
|{{convert|28|mi|km|}}
|'''21 deaths''' — Began near [[Polk City, Iowa|Polk City]], and moved east-southeast north of [[Des Moines, Iowa|Des Moines]]. Several homes were leveled on the north sides of [[Bondurant, Iowa|Bondurant]] and [[Valeria, Iowa|Valeria]], resulting in multiple fatalities. Other homes were destroyed and fatalities occurred in the communities of [[Santiago, Iowa|Santiago]] and Mingo. A steel railroad rail was driven {{convert|15|ft|m|}} into the ground at one location. At least 60 people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 />
|-
|colspan="7"|<small>Sources: Grazulis (1993)<ref name=Grazulis3 /></small>
|}
{{clear}}

===May 25 event===
{| class="wikitable toccolours collapsible" style="width:100%;"
!colspan="6"|List of confirmed tornadoes - May 25, 1896
|-
|'''<center>[[Fujita scale|F#]]'''</center> || <center>'''Location'''</center> || <center>'''County'''</center> || <center>'''Time (UTC)'''</center> || <center>'''Path length'''</center> || <center>'''Damage'''</center>
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Illinois]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat4}} | <big>'''F4'''</big>
|'''NW of [[Forreston, Illinois|Forreston]] to S of [[Egan, Illinois|Egan]]'''
|[[Ogle County, Illinois|Ogle]]
|0700
|{{convert|10|mi|km|}}
|'''4 deaths''' — Multiple homes had their roofs torn off on the northern edge of [[Adeline, Illinois|Adeline]]. In rural areas, a church and five farm homes were leveled. Four fatalities occurred south of Egan, where a large home was cleanly swept away.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''S of [[Byron, Illinois|Byron]]'''
|[[Ogle County, Illinois|Ogle]]
|0730
|unknown
|All barns and trees were destroyed on a farm.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''S of [[Davis Junction, Illinois|Davis Junction]] to E of [[Irene, Illinois|Irene]]'''
|[[Ogle County, Illinois|Ogle]], [[Boone County, Illinois|Boone]], [[DeKalb County, Illinois|DeKalb]]
|0730
|{{convert|15|mi|km|}}
|'''3 deaths''' — Buildings were destroyed on 11 farms. Six people were injured and three others were killed in a collapsed home. Debris from that home was found five miles away. A barn was destroyed in DeKalb County as well.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''[[Edison Park, Chicago|Edison Park]]'''
|[[Cook County, Illinois|Cook]]
|0750
|{{convert|4.5|mi|km|}}
|Tornado struck the communities of [[Park Ridge, Illinois|Park Ridge]], Edison Park, and [[Norwood Park, Chicago|Norwood Park]].  Six homes were destroyed and 30 others were damaged beyond repair. Caused $100,000 in damage and hit within {{convert|15|mi|km|}} of [[downtown Chicago|downtown]] [[Chicago]].<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Michigan]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''N of [[Clio, Michigan|Clio]] to E of [[Otter Lake, Michigan|Otter Lake]]'''
|[[Genesee County, Michigan|Genesee]], [[Lapeer County, Michigan|Lapeer]]
|2300
|{{convert|14|mi|km|}}
|Businesses and cottages were destroyed at Otter Lake. Three farm homes were destroyed, and the roof of a school was carried for half a mile. Four people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''W of [[Munger, Michigan|Munger]] to [[Fairgrove, Michigan|Fairgrove]] area'''
|[[Bay County, Michigan|Bay]], [[Tuscola County, Michigan|Tuscola]]
|2300
|{{convert|10|mi|km|}}
|'''1 death''' — A school and five homes were destroyed along the path. 30 people were attending a funeral at one of the homes, and the attendants survived by taking shelter in a nearby ditch as the house was lifted and destroyed. One man was killed by flying debris as he watched from his window.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''W of [[Sterling Heights, Michigan|Sterling Heights]] to [[Harrison Township, Michigan|Harrison Township]]'''
|[[Macomb County, Michigan|Macomb]], [[St. Clair County, Michigan|St. Clair]]
|0110
|{{convert|35|mi|km|}}
|'''2 deaths''' — Homes and barns were leveled between Warren and Utica before the tornado tore through [[Mt. Clemens, Michigan|Mt. Clemens]], where 30 homes were destroyed along a two-block-wide path. Homes were destroyed in other areas before the tornado crossed into [[Ontario]], where $60,000 in damage occurred.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat5}} | <big>'''F5'''</big>
|'''N of [[Holly, Michigan|Holly]] to W of [[Dryden, Michigan|Dryden]]'''
|[[Oakland County, Michigan|Oakland]], [[Lapeer County, Michigan|Lapeer]]
|0200
|{{convert|30|mi|km|}}
|'''47 deaths''' — ''[[May 1896 tornado outbreak sequence#Ortonville/Thomas/Oakwood, Michigan|See section on this tornado]]'' — Extremely intense tornado,<ref name=F5 /> second deadliest in Michigan.<ref name=Grazulis3 />
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''[[Amadore, Michigan|Amadore]]'''
|[[Sanilac County, Michigan|Sanilac]]
|0200
|{{convert|3|mi|km|}}
|Every building in the village of Amadore was damaged to some degree, and two homes were destroyed at that location. The tornado moved out over [[Lake Huron]] as a [[waterspout]]. Three people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|colspan="7"|<small>Sources: Grazulis (1993)<ref name=Grazulis3 /> </small>
|}

===May 27 event===
{| class="wikitable toccolours collapsible" style="width:100%;"
!colspan="6"|List of confirmed tornadoes - May 27, 1896
|-
|'''<center>[[Fujita scale|F#]]'''</center> || <center>'''Location'''</center> || <center>'''County'''</center> || <center>'''Time (UTC)'''</center> || <center>'''Path length'''</center> || <center>'''Damage'''</center>
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Missouri]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''E of [[Bellflower, Missouri|Bellflower]]'''
|[[Montgomery County, Missouri|Montgomery]], [[Lincoln County, Missouri|Lincoln]]
|unknown
|{{convert|7|mi|km|}}
|'''1 death''' — A church and a barn were destroyed. A woman was killed and her infant son was injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 />
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''N of [[Sturgeon, Missouri|Sturgeon]] to N of [[Centralia, Missouri|Centralia]]'''
|[[Audrain County, Missouri|Audrain]]
|1935
|{{convert|8|mi|km|}}
|Barns leveled destroyed and four farm homes were "nearly destroyed".<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''S of [[Higbee, Missouri|Higbee]] to S of [[Renick, Missouri|Renick]]'''
|[[Randolph County, Missouri|Randolph]]
|2030
|{{convert|6|mi|km|}}
|Three homes were destroyed and five others were damaged. Many barns were destroyed as well. Six people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''N of [[Mexico, Missouri|Mexico]] to W of [[Vandalia, Missouri|Vandalia]]'''
|[[Audrain County, Missouri|Audrain]]
|2115
|{{convert|17|mi|km|}}
|'''6-7 deaths''' — Three students were killed at the Dye school, and one student (possibly two) was killed at the Bean Creek School. Two others died in farmhouses. A total of 50 people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat4}} | <big>'''F4'''</big>
|'''SE of [[Chamois, Missouri|Chamois]]'''
|[[Osage County, Missouri|Osage]]
|0015
|{{convert|5|mi|km|}}
|'''2 deaths''' — Two farms were destroyed, at one of which every building was completely swept away. Three people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 />
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat4}} | <big>'''F4'''</big>
|'''[[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]]/[[East St. Louis, Illinois|East St. Louis, IL]]'''
|[[St. Louis County, Missouri|St.Louis]], [[Madison County, Illinois|Madison]] (IL)
|0030
|{{convert|12|mi|km|}}
|'''255 deaths''' — [[1896 St. Louis – East St. Louis tornado|See article on this tornado]] — Third-deadliest tornado in US history,<ref name=Grazulis3 /> caused near-F5 damage in East St. Louis.<ref name=F5 />
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Illinois]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat4}} | <big>'''F4'''</big>
|'''E of [[New Minden, Illinois|New Minden]] to [[Irvington, Illinois|Irvington]]'''
|[[Washington County, Illinois|Washington]], [[Jefferson County, Illinois|Jefferson]]
|0020
|{{convert|23|mi|km|}}
|'''14 deaths''' — Entire farms were leveled near [[New Minden, Illinois|New Minden]], south of [[Hoyleton, Illinois|Hoyleton]], near [[Richview, Illinois|Richview]], and in [[Boyd, Illinois|Boyd]] and [[Irvington, Illinois|Irvington]]. 50 others were injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat4}} | <big>'''F4'''</big>
|'''E of [[Imbs, Illinois|Imbs]] to NE of [[Germantown, Illinois|Germantown]]'''
|[[St. Clair County, Illinois|St. Clair]], [[Clinton County, Illinois|Clinton]]
|0045
|{{convert|30|mi|km|}}
|'''24 deaths''' — The path of this tornado family may have begun in [[Dupo, Illinois|Dupo]]. Many homes were leveled along the path, especially in and around [[New Baden, Illinois|New Baden]], where 13 people died. Near the beginning of the path, 10 people died near train stations, and another death occurred at a farmhouse near Germantown before the tornado dissipated. 125 people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis4>Grazulis, Significant, p. 677</ref>
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''NW of [[Nashville, Illinois|Nashville]] to NE of [[Mt. Vernon, Illinois|Mt. Vernon]]'''
|[[Washington County, Illinois|Washington]], [[Jefferson County, Illinois|Jefferson]]
|0230
|{{convert|28|mi|km|}}
|'''3 deaths''' — Many farms were devastated along the path. Damage northeast of Mt. Vernon may have been downburst-related.<ref name=Grazulis4 />
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Oklahoma]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''E of [[Hennessey, Oklahoma|Hennessey]] to NE of [[Marshall, Oklahoma|Marshall]]'''
|[[Kingfisher County, Oklahoma|Kingfisher]], [[Logan County, Oklahoma|Logan]], [[Garfield County, Oklahoma|Garfield]]
|0000
|{{convert|10|mi|km|}}
|A house was blown apart and scattered. One person was injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 />
|-
|colspan="7"|<small>Sources: Grazulis (1993)<ref name=Grazulis3 /><ref name=Grazulis4 /></small>
|}

===May 28 event===
{| class="wikitable toccolours collapsible" style="width:100%;"
!colspan="6"|List of confirmed tornadoes - May 28, 1896
|-
|'''<center>[[Fujita scale|F#]]'''</center> || <center>'''Location'''</center> || <center>'''County'''</center> || <center>'''Time (UTC)'''</center> || <center>'''Path length'''</center> || <center>'''Damage'''</center>
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Pennsylvania]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''E of [[Gettysburg, Pennsylvania|Gettysburg]] to NE of [[Hanover, Pennsylvania|Hanover]]'''
|[[Adams County, Pennsylvania|Adams]], [[York County, Pennsylvania|York]]
|1800
|{{convert|13|mi|km|}}
|Barns were destroyed near [[Bonneauville, Pennsylvania|Bonneauville]] and [[Abbottstown, Pennsylvania|Abbottstown]]. A house was leveled as well, with the furniture carried over half a mile away. Four people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis4 />
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''[[Columbia, Pennsylvania|Columbia]]/[[Wrightsville, Pennsylvania|Wrightsville]] areas'''
|[[York County, Pennsylvania|York]], [[Lancaster County, Pennsylvania|Lancaster]]
|1830
|{{convert|9|mi|km|}}
|'''1 death''' — A school and four homes had their roofs torn off in Wrightsville. One person was killed when the tornado struck a rolling mill in Columbia, where three homes were destroyed. 20 people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis4 /> 
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat3}} | <big>'''F3'''</big>
|'''S of [[Ambler, Pennsylvania|Ambler]] to S of [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton, NJ]]'''
|[[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Montgomery]], [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Bucks]], [[Mercer County, New Jersey|Mercer]](NJ), [[Monmouth County, New Jersey|Monmouth]](NJ)
|1955
|{{convert|35|mi|km|}}
|'''4 deaths''' — 16 barns and several stables were destroyed in Pennsylvania, where four people were killed. The tornado crossed into New Jersey and damaged businesses in [[Allentown, New Jersey|Allentown]] and [[White Horse, New Jersey|White Horse]]. 15 people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis4 /> 
|-
| colspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|'''[[Maryland]]'''
|-
|bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|cat2}} | <big>'''F2'''</big>
|'''SW of [[Harney, Maryland|Harney]] to [[Littlestown, Pennsylvania|Littlestown, PA]], area'''
|[[Carroll County, Maryland|Carroll]], [[Adams County, Pennsylvania|Adams]](PA)
|2000
|{{convert|5|mi|km|}}
|In Maryland, a house was torn apart and three others had their roofs torn off. Furniture was carried up to half a mile away. Crossed into Pennsylvania and dissapated near Littlestown, where barns were destroyed.<ref name=Grazulis5>Grazulis, Significant, p. 678</ref>
|-
|colspan="7"|<small>Sources: Grazulis (1993)<ref name=Grazulis4 /><ref name=Grazulis5 /></small>
|}
{{clear}}

==Notable tornadoes==

===Sherman, Texas===
On the first day of the outbreak sequence, most of the fatalities came from a single supercell thunderstorm that traveled from [[Denton, Texas|Denton]] to Sherman. The tornado began in the Pilot Point area, where farm homes were shifted off of their foundations. The tornado widened and strengthened into a very violent F5 and swept away numerous farms west of [[Farmington, Denton County, Texas|Farmington]] and [[Howe, Texas|Howe]]. Later along the path, the tornado narrowed to around {{convert|60|yd|ft|}} wide as it tore through Sherman. Fifty homes were destroyed in town, 20 of which were completely obliterated and swept away. An iron-beam bridge was torn from its supports and twisted into multiple pieces, and one of the beams was driven several feet into the ground.<ref name="F5">{{Cite book| last=Grazulis|first=Thomas P.|authorlink=Thomas P. Grazulis|title=F5-F6 Tornadoes|publisher=The Tornado Project|year=2001|location=St. Johnsbury, VT|isbn= }}</ref><ref name="rootsweb.ancestry.com">http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~txgrayso/Black-Friday/black11.html</ref> Bodies were found up to {{convert|400|yd|ft|}} from their home sites, and a trunk lid was carried for {{convert|35|mi|km|}}. Headstones at a cemetery were shattered, and a 500-pound stone was carried for 250 yards. Trees in the area were completely debarked with some reduced to stumps, and grass was scoured from lawns in town.<ref name="rootsweb.ancestry.com"/> At least 200 people were injured, and bodies of the victims were transported into the courthouse and a vacant building. Several bodies were recovered from a muddy creek.<ref>[http://www3.gendisasters.com/texas/2894/sherman,-tx-tornado,-may-1896 Sherman, TX Tornado, May 1896 | GenDisasters ... Genealogy in Tragedy, Disasters, Fires, Floods<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Seventy-three people were killed by this single tornado, one of the worst on record in North Texas and the [[Red River of the South|Red River Valley]] region.

Additional killer tornadoes were recorded north of [[Wichita, Kansas]] in [[McPherson County, Kansas|McPherson County]] and further south in [[Bryan County, Oklahoma]].<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://www.tornadoproject.com/past/pastts95.htm Tornadoes in the Past<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
{{clear}}

===Seneca/Oneida, Kansas/Falls City, Nebraska===
A powerful F5 tornado,<ref name=Grazulis3 /> estimated to have been more than {{convert|2|mi|km|}} wide, tore through the towns of [[Seneca, Kansas|Seneca]], [[Oneida, Kansas|Oneida]], [[Reserve, Kansas|Reserve]] and [[Sabetha, Kansas]]. In Seneca, the tornado destroyed the courthouse and a new schoolhouse, and the opera house was completely leveled and swept away. Damage in Seneca alone was estimated at around $250,000 (in 1896 Dollars) where most of the homes, the fairgrounds and other small structures sustained at least heavy, if not complete, damage.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name="seneca-ks1">[http://www.seneca-ks.com/book2/pres0006.htm County Court House 1878<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name="seneca-ks2">[http://www.seneca-ks.com/book2/tornado.htm Tornado destroyed Seneca, Ks<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The damage path was two miles wide at Reserve, and only three buildings were left undamaged at that location. The tornado damaged 50 homes and destroyed 20 others on the north side of Sabetha. Many farms were entirely swept away along the path as well, some of which were reportedly left "as bare as the prairie".<ref name=F5 /> The tornado continued into Nebraska, where four people died and damage occurred on the south side of Falls City. At least 200 people were injured. 
{{clear}}

===Ortonville/Thomas/Oakwood, Michigan===
Late during the evening hours of May 25, an F5 tornado<ref name=Grazulis3 /> touched down in eastern Michigan and moved northeast for about {{convert|30|mi|km|0}}. The tornado affected portions of [[Oakland County, Michigan|Oakland]], [[Lapeer County, Michigan|Lapeer]] and [[Livingston County, Michigan|Livingston]] Counties northwest of [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]]. Towns affected included [[Oxford Charter Township, Michigan|Thomas]], [[Ortonville, Michigan|Ortonville]], [[Oakwood, Michigan|Oakwood]], and [[Grand Blanc Township, Michigan#Communities|Whigville]] just after 9:00 pm. Homes were leveled or swept away, and multiple fatalities occurred along the path. Entire farms were leveled, and debris from homes was found up to {{convert|12|mi|km|}} away. Trees were completely debarked along the path as well, with even small twigs stripped bare in some cases. Homes were swept away in Thomas, including one that was obliterated with the debris scattered up to 10 miles away. A piano from that residence was found 200 yards away from the foundation, with one end "pounded full of grass". Weather Bureau inspectors reported that grass in the center-most part of the circulation was "pounded down into the earth, as if it had been washed into the earth by a heavy flow of water."<ref>http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/024/mwr-024-05-0156a.pdf</ref> At least 100 people were injured.<ref name=Grazulis3 />  With 47 deaths, this is the second-deadliest tornado ever in [[Michigan]] trailing only the [[1953 Flint-Beecher tornado|Flint Tornado]] of 1953 which killed 116 in [[Genessee County, Michigan|Genessee County]] just outside [[Flint, Michigan|Flint]]. Twenty-two people were killed in Ortonville, ten in Oakwood, three in Thomas, four north of [[Oxford, Michigan|Oxford]] and three in [[Whigville, Michigan|Whigville]] with others in rural areas. Nine of the fatalities were in a single home in Ortonville.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.tornadoproject.com/alltorns/worstts.htm The United States' Worst Tornadoes<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>http://www.a2gov.org/government/safetyservices/emergencymanagement/Pages/TornadoHistory.aspx</ref>

Other killer tornadoes on that day touched down in [[Ogle County, Illinois]] (two different tornadoes) and [[Macomb County, Michigan|Macomb]] & [[Tuscola County, Michigan|Tuscola Counties]] in Michigan. Several homes and farms in the [[Mount Clemens, Michigan|Mount Clemens]] area were wiped out and others were moved from their foundations. The recently completed Colonial Hotel was leveled. Thirty homes were leveled in total, and two people were killed.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref>[http://www.macomb.lib.mi.us/mountclemens/tornado.htm Great Tornado of 1896<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
{{clear}}

===St. Louis, Missouri/East St. Louis, Illinois===
{{Main|St. Louis-East St. Louis Tornado}}
The third deadliest tornado in United States history struck [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]] city and its metropolitan area on both sides of the [[Mississippi River]] in [[Missouri]] and [[Illinois]] on May 27. Preceded by a hurricane that nearly destroyed the city with electrical and water damage, that tornado alone at least killed 255, injuring thousands and destroying 50 million property value.<ref>{{Cite book|url = http://hdl.handle.net/2027/loc.ark:/13960/t3bz6h22q|title = The great St. Louis cyclone,|last = Hammer|first = Ludwig F. jr [from old catalog|publisher = [St. Louis, Mo.,}}</ref>  This tornado in addition killed 27 other people elsewhere in Illinois and seven elsewhere in Missouri including three at a school in [[Audrain County, Missouri|Audrain County]]. Twenty-four of the 27 other fatalities were recorded by a single tornado with 13 of them near [[New Baden, Illinois|New Baden]]. In that town about half of the homes were completely destroyed with damage figures at around $50,000. The towns of [[Belleville, Illinois|Belleville]] and [[Mascoutah, Illinois|Mascoutah]] were also hit. Three people were killed by the other killer tornado that tracked between [[Nashville, Illinois|Nashville]] and [[Mount Vernon, Illinois|Mount Vernon]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref>[http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ilx/svrclimo.php National Weather Service, Lincoln IL - Severe Weather Climatology<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.gendisasters.com/data1/il/tornadoes/newbaden-tornado1896.htm New Baden, IL Tornado, May 1896]</ref> Fatalities were also reported the following day in [[Pennsylvania]] and [[New Jersey]] near [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]] between [[Philadelphia]] and [[New York City]].<ref name=autogenerated2 />
{{clear}}

==See also==
* [[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]]

[[Image:Information.svg|left|25px|alt=|link=]] Hello, and welcome to Wikipedia. This is a message letting you know that one of your recent edits to [[:Administrative reforms in Kerala]] has been undone by an automated computer program called [[User:ClueBot NG|ClueBot NG]].
{{clear}}
* ClueBot NG makes very few [[User:ClueBot NG#Information About False Positives|mistakes]], but it does happen. If you believe the change you made was constructive, please [[User:ClueBot NG#Information About False Positives|read about it]], [{{User:ClueBot NG/Warnings/FPReport|1686450}} report it here], remove this message from your talk page, and then make the edit again.

title: Gigantosaurus
User talk:Theunissen~enwiki
content:
== Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Theunissen. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Theunissen~enwiki that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. If you think you might own all of the accounts with this name and this message is in error, please visit [[Special:MergeAccount]] to check and attach all of your accounts to prevent them from being renamed. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
03:04, 20 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

title: Peeter van Aelst
content:
'''Peter van Aelst''', '''Peeter van Aelst''' or '''Pieter van Aelst''' is the name of a number of artists including:

*[[Pieter Coecke van Aelst]], a Flemish painter of the 16th century
*Peeter van Aelst, a 17th-century Dutch still life painter referred to by Cornelis de Bie in his [[Het Gulden Cabinet]]
*[[Pieter van Aelst (Antwerp)|Pieter van Aelst]], a 17th-century Flemish genre painter active in Antwerp from 1644 to 1654.

{{disambiguation}}

title: Gmina Troszyn
content:
{{Infobox settlement | name = Gmina Troszyn | other_name = Troszyn Commune | settlement_type = [[Gmina]] | total_type = Total | image_flag = | image_shield = | image_map = | coordinates_display = inline,title | coordinates_region = PL | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = {{POL}} | subdivision_type1 = [[Voivodeships of Poland|Voivodeship]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Masovian Voivodeship|Masovian]] | subdivision_type2 = [[Powiat|County]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Ostrołęka County]] | area_total_km2 = 156.31 | population_total = 4945| population_as_of = 2011[http://stat.gov.pl/en/topics/population/population/ Demographic Yearbook of Poland 2012] | population_density_km2 = auto | coor_pinpoint = Troszyn | latd = 53 | latm = 1 | lats = 49 | latNS = N | longd = 21 | longm = 44 | longs = 9 | longEW = E | seat = [[Troszyn, Masovian Voivodeship|Troszyn]] | website = }} __NOTOC__ '''Gmina Troszyn''' is a rural [[gmina]] (administrative district) in [[Ostrołęka County]], [[Masovian Voivodeship]], in east-central [[Poland]]. Its seat is the village of [[Troszyn, Masovian Voivodeship|Troszyn]], which lies approximately {{convert|13|km|mi|0}} east of [[Ostrołęka]] and {{convert|104|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} north-east of [[Warsaw]]. The gmina covers an area of {{convert|156.31|km2|sqmi|1}}, and as of 2006 its total population is 4,880 (4,945 in 2011). ==Villages== Gmina Troszyn contains the villages and settlements of [[Aleksandrowo, Gmina Troszyn|Aleksandrowo]], [[Borowce, Masovian Voivodeship|Borowce]], [[Budne, Masovian Voivodeship|Budne]], [[Choromany]], [[Chrostowo, Masovian Voivodeship|Chrostowo]], [[Chrzczony, Ostrołęka County|Chrzczony]], [[Dąbek, Gmina Troszyn|Dąbek]], [[Dzbenin, Gmina Troszyn|Dzbenin]], [[Grucele]], [[Janochy]], [[Kamionowo]], [[Kleczkowo]], [[Kurpie Dworskie]], [[Kurpie Szlacheckie]], [[Łątczyn Szlachecki]], [[Łątczyn Włościański]], [[Mieczki-Abramy]], [[Mieczki-Poziemaki]], [[Mieczki-Ziemaki]], [[Milewo Wielkie]], [[Milewo-Łosie]], [[Milewo-Tosie]], [[Ojcewo]], [[Opęchowo]], [[Puchały, Ostrołęka County|Puchały]], [[Rabędy, Ostrołęka County|Rabędy]], [[Radgoszcz, Masovian Voivodeship|Radgoszcz]], [[Repki, Ostrołęka County|Repki]], [[Rostki, Ostrołęka County|Rostki]], [[Sawały]], [[Siemiątkowo, Ostrołęka County|Siemiątkowo]], [[Stare Janki]], [[Troszyn, Masovian Voivodeship|Troszyn]], [[Trzaski, Ostrołęka County|Trzaski]], [[Wysocarz]], [[Zamość, Ostrołęka County|Zamość]], [[Zapieczne]], [[Zawady, Gmina Troszyn|Zawady]], [[Żmijewo-Zagroby]], [[Żmijówek Włościański]], [[Żmijówek-Mans]] and [[Żyźniewo]]. ==Neighbouring gminas== Gmina Troszyn is bordered by the gminas of [[Gmina Czerwin|Czerwin]], [[Gmina Miastkowo|Miastkowo]], [[Gmina Rzekuń|Rzekuń]] and [[Gmina Śniadowo|Śniadowo]]. ==References== {{reflist|1}} *[http://www.stat.gov.pl/gus/45_655_PLK_HTML.htm Polish official population figures 2006]

content: '''Welcome!''' Hello, Gerrillmuto, and [[Wikipedia:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]] to Wikipedia! I hope you like the place and decide to stay. Unfortunately, one or more of the pages you created, such as [[Noorm]], may not conform to some of Wikipedia's [[Wikipedia:List of policies|guidelines]], and may soon be deleted. There's a page about creating articles you may want to read called '''[[Wikipedia:Your first article|Your first article]]'''. If you are stuck, and looking for help, please come to the '''[[Wikipedia:New contributors' help page|New contributors' help page]]''', where experienced Wikipedians can answer any queries you have! Or, you can just type '''{{t|helpme}}''' on this page, and someone will show up shortly to answer your questions. Here are a few other good links for newcomers: * [[Wikipedia:Starting an article|Starting an article]] * [[Wikipedia:Your first article|Your first article]] * [[Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons|Biographies of living persons]] * [[Wikipedia:How to write a great article|How to write a great article]] * [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] * [[Help:Contents|Help pages]] * [[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Signatures|sign your name]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your name and the date. If you have any questions, check out [[Wikipedia:Questions]] or ask me on my talk page. Again, welcome! [[User:MarB4|MarB4]] [[user talk:MarB4|•ɯɒɹ•]] 15:32, 16 June 2011 (UTC) ==[[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|Speedy deletion]] nomination of [[:Noorm]]== [[Image:Ambox warning pn.svg|48px|left|alt=|link=]] Please refrain from introducing inappropriate pages, such as [[:Noorm]], to Wikipedia. Doing so is not in accordance with our [[Wikipedia:List of policies|policies]]. If you would like to experiment, please use the [[Wikipedia:Sandbox|sandbox]]. If you think that this notice was placed here in error, contest the deletion by clicking on the button labelled "Click here to contest this speedy deletion," which appears inside of the speedy deletion ({{db-...}}) tag (if no such tag exists, the page is no longer a speedy delete candidate). Doing so will take you to the talk page where you will find a pre-formatted place for you to explain why you believe the page should not be deleted. You can also visit the '''[[Talk:Noorm|the page's talk page directly]]''' to give your reasons, but be aware that once tagged for ''speedy'' deletion, if the page meets the criterion, it may be deleted without delay. Please do not remove the speedy deletion tag yourself, but don't hesitate to add information to the page that would render it more in conformance with Wikipedia's policies and guidelines. [[User:MarB4|MarB4]] [[user talk:MarB4|•ɯɒɹ•]] 15:32, 16 June 2011 (UTC)

'''Stull''' is an [[unincorporated community]] in [[Douglas County, Kansas|Douglas County]], [[Kansas]], United States.<ref name="GNIS"/>

==History==

===19th century===
Originally called '''Deer Creek''' Community,<ref name=clintonlake>Martha Parker & Betty Laird.  ''Soil of Our Souls:  Histories of the Clinton Lake Communities''.  Parker-Laird Enterprises, 1976, 94-104.</ref> the area was settled mainly by people of [[Germans|German]] ancestry, mainly [[Pennsylvania Dutch]].  By 1857, six families were living in the vicinity.  Descendants of the original founders still reside in the community.  In 1859, the settlers organized the Evangelical Emmanuel Church and by 1867 the members had collected enough funds to construct a stone church on land donated by Jacob Hildenbrand for that purpose and a cemetery.  Until 1908, the sermons were preached in [[German language|German]].<ref name=clintonlake />

===20th century===
The Stull Church of Christ was started in 1907, and by 1913 a frame church was built in town.  A post office was established on April 27, 1899 and was named Stull after the first and only postmaster Sylvester Stull.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JroyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hegFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6612%2C4399216 | title=What's in a name? Key elements of area history | work=Lawrence Journal-World | date=November 28, 1997 | accessdate=28 April 2015 | author=Carpenter, Tim | pages=3B}}</ref>  The post office was discontinued in 1903.  In the early 1920s, plans for a bank and an electric railway extension through Lawrence to [[Emporia, Kansas|Emporia]] were cancelled.

In the early 20th century, Stull suffered two tragedies.  A young boy was found burned to death after his father had finished burning a field and a man was found hanging from a tree after going missing.<ref name=clintonlake />

===21st century===

The old Evangelical Church, built in 1867, was torn down in March 2002. The church was subject to occult rumors and was often vandalized.<ref>{{cite news |work=Lawrence Journal-World |title=Building's Demolition a Mystery |url=http://www2.ljworld.com/news/2002/mar/30/buildings_demolition_a/ |date=2002-03-30}}</ref>

==Geography==
Stull is located at {{coord|38|58|16|N|95|27|32|W|type:city}} (38.9711124, -95.4560872),<ref name="GNIS"/> at the corner of North 1600 Road ({{jct|state=KS|CR|442|county1=Douglas}}) and East 250 Road ({{jct|state=KS|CR|1023|county1=Douglas}}) in [[Douglas County, Kansas|Douglas County]], which is 7 miles west of [[Lawrence, Kansas|Lawrence]] and 10 miles east of [[Topeka, Kansas|Topeka]].

==Stull Cemetery==
[[Image:Stull ks cemetery.JPG|thumb|right|Stull Cemetery in 2007]]
The '''Stull Cemetery'''<ref>[http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=gnispq:3:::NO::P3_FID:2673257 Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) details for Stull Cemetery, Kansas; United States Geological Survey (USGS); July 22, 2011.]</ref> has gained a dubious reputation due to [[urban legend]]s involving [[Satan]], the [[occult]], and a purported "gateway to [[Hell]]".<ref name="lawrence20041026">{{cite news |work=Lawrence.com |title=Hell Hath No Fury |url=http://www.lawrence.com/news/2004/oct/26/stull/ |date=2004-10-26}}</ref>  The 1867 stone church on the north side of the cemetery was knocked down in 2002.<ref name="lawrence20041026"/>  

Local police have discouraged curiosity seekers from entering the cemetery, especially on [[Halloween]], and some people have been arrested for trespassing.<ref>{{cite news |work=Lawrence Journal-World |title=Legends Linger Around Stull |url=http://www2.ljworld.com/news/1999/nov/01/legends_linger_around_stull/ |date=1999-11-01}}</ref>  When the cemetery is closed, trespassing could bring a maximum fine of $1,000 and up to six months in jail.<ref name="lawrence20041026"/>

The band [[Urge Overkill]] released ''Stull EP'' in 1992, which features the church and a tombstone from the cemetery on the cover.<ref>[http://www.touchandgorecords.com/images/catalog/fullsize/337-1.jpg Urge Overkill - Stull EP - Cover Art.]</ref>  Films whose plot is based on the legends include ''[[Sin-Jin Smyth]]'', ''[[Nothing Left to Fear (film)|Nothing Left to Fear]]'', and ''[[Turbulence 3: Heavy Metal]]''.  The cemetery is the site of the final confrontation of the [[Apocalypse]] in the "[[Swan Song (Supernatural)|Swan Song]]" episode of [[Supernatural (season 5)|season five]] of the television series ''[[Supernatural (U.S. TV series)|Supernatural]]''.

==See also==
* [[Kanwaka Township, Douglas County, Kansas]] (location of Stull)
* [[Clinton Lake (Kansas)|Clinton Lake]], southeast of Stull
* [[List of reportedly haunted locations in the United States]]

==References==
{{Reflist}}

==Further reading==
* ''The History of Stull, 1857-1976''; Stull Bicentennial Committee; 8 pages; 1976.

==External links==

title: Talk:Nightfall (Asimov short story and novel)
content: {{Talk header |search=yes}} {{User:MiszaBot/config |archiveheader = {{talk archive navigation}} |maxarchivesize = 70K |counter = 1 |minthreadsleft = 4 |minthreadstoarchive = 1 |algo = old(180d) |archive = Talk:Nightfall (Asimov short story and novel)/Archive %(counter)d }} {{WikiProject Novels|class=Start |importance=Mid |short-story-task-force=yes |sf-task-force=yes }} {{WikiProject Science Fiction|class=Start|importance=Mid}} ==Credibility?== {{collapse top|Discussion not directed to improvement of the article|The following is a closed discussion about the work, but not directed to improving the article. '''Please do not modify it.''' See [[WP:NOTAFORUM]].}} I don't know when I read Nightfall - 1950s or 60s - but I do recall being so dissatisfied at its ending. How were we supposed to believe in a planet which had several times achieved intelligent life but didn't know even the concept of darkness? Which means their very first habitations, of course needed in inclement weather let alone cold/wet seasons, must have been made of glass? So they discovered how to make glass as soon as they were able to manage fire? Oh, OK, their six suns meant they never had seasons. But each time an intelligent life form developed, it never thought to explore inside any cave or pothole? And they'd reached highly advanced stages without ever needing to sink mineshafts. So they didn't understand the notion of a lamp? I can't be the only person who realized these things as soon as finishing reading the story, so it's a puzzle to me how it's consistently said to be the greatest scifi work ever, or some such. I loved Azimov's stories when I was young, particularly the Foundation series. But how can it be said that Nightfall is the greatest ever when it's built on such a non-credible situation? [[User:L0ngpar1sh|L0ngpar1sh]] ([[User talk:L0ngpar1sh|talk]]) 21:10, 21 December 2010 (UTC) :When the short story was originally published, the physics of multistar systems of order six were not yet understood. Planetary formation theories was drawn from a sample of 1 (the Solar System) And habitability of planets is still not really understood. We now know they are tiered binary systems. And the physics of the situation only need to exist for a few cycles, long enough for the people to not know about a past where there was a night, or a visible moon, and for several eclipse periods to have happened. It doesn't need to have existed any longer than that. Before that period, there could have been a visible moon and night. And in the far future of the world, there could be again. -- [[Special:Contributions/65.94.169.222|65.94.169.222]] ([[User talk:65.94.169.222|talk]]) 11:27, 27 July 2014 (UTC) {{collapse bottom}} == Planet's and stars' name == "[[Lagash]]" is a well-known Middle East archaeological site (according to the En. Brit., "one of the most important capital cities in ancient Sumer, " Is there is evidence that IA intentionally chose this name rather than that he simply made up a name out of English phonemes?[[User:Kdammers|Kdammers]] ([[User talk:Kdammers|talk]]) 01:22, 3 April 2014 (UTC) The stars Trey and Patru are probably the numbers 3 and 4 in Romanian (3 written to match the pronunciation), see [[Romanian_numbers]]. Moreover, they are on places 3 and 4 in the list following the stars named by Greek letters. There are parallels to numbers in the others as well, so maybe from another language? [[Special:Contributions/129.247.247.238|129.247.247.238]] ([[User talk:129.247.247.238|talk]]) 10:33, 17 November 2014 (UTC) The name Saro City is likely derived from "[[Saros_(astronomy)|Saros]]" which is one type of [[eclipse cycle]]. — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/2601:600:8600:6242:B89C:B297:6782:AAAA|2601:600:8600:6242:B89C:B297:6782:AAAA]] ([[User talk:2601:600:8600:6242:B89C:B297:6782:AAAA|talk]]) 20:24, 13 March 2016 (UTC) == the reality of Kalgash == Someone's done a study on the physical feasibility of the system as described in the story. * {{cite journal |title= Nightfall: Can Kalgash Exist |author= Smaran Deshmukh, Jayant Murthy |date= 18 July 2014 |arxiv= 1407.4895 |bibcode= 2014arXiv1407.4895D |publicationdate= July 2014 }} -- [[Special:Contributions/65.94.169.222|65.94.169.222]] ([[User talk:65.94.169.222|talk]]) 11:22, 27 July 2014 (UTC) == Massive Plot Hole == Surely the opposite side of the planet would remain in light from the other suns and the unaffected civilisations there would recolonise? — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Stub Mandrel|Stub Mandrel]] ([[User talk:Stub Mandrel|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Stub Mandrel|contribs]]) 13:27, 18 July 2015 (UTC) :I remember wondering about that when I first read the story, but on a later re-read, I noticed that it was covered: "The eclipse that results, with the moon seven times the apparent diameter of Beta, covers all of Lagash and lasts well over half a day, so that no spot on the planet escapes the effects." The novelization's cover image might be flawed here -- if that's the "diamond ring" effect of an Earth-viewed eclipse, it would imply bodies of roughly equal angular size, I think. But I'm not sure; maybe the light from a smaller sun would still illuminate the moon's edge like that. Is it in fact a mistake, and if so, has any reliable source noted it? [[User:Joule36e5|Joule36e5]] ([[User talk:Joule36e5|talk]]) 22:19, 5 August 2015 (UTC)

'''James Williams''' (born [[Circa|c.]] 1960) better known as '''D-Train''' is an [[United States|American]] [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] [[singer-songwriter]] and [[actor]], best known as [[lead vocalist]] for [[D-Train|the duo of the same name]] in the 1980s, as well as co-writing and performing the "[[Pokémon 2.B.A. Master|Pokérap]]" from the popular [[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon anime]].

==Biography==
James Williams was born in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]] in the 1960s. He began singing from the age of 6 in church and school [[choir]]s, and was given the nickname "D-Train" during his studies at [[Erasmus Hall High School]], due to his powerful [[Defensive_tackle#Defensive_tackle|defensive tackle]] in the [[American football|football]] team. It was at Erasmus that Williams' classmate, future [[record producer]] [[Will Downing]], introduced him to [[keyboardist]] [[Hubert Eaves III]] with whom he performed. After Eaves' stint in [[Mtume]] during the 1970s, he and Williams would come together again in 1980 to form [[D-Train]], named after Williams' own nickname.<ref>http://www.jamesdtrainwilliams.com/bio.html</ref>

===D-Train===
{{Main|D-Train}}
D-Train released their first single, "[[You're the One for Me (D. Train song)|You're the One for Me]]" in 1981, which hit #1 on the [[Hot Dance Club Play]] chart. In 1982, the duo released their first album, ''[[D. Train (album)|D-Train, a.k.a. You're the One for Me]]'', which, as well as the title track, spawned two other successful singles with "[[Keep On (song)|Keep On]]" and a cover of [[Burt Bacharach]] and [[Hal David]]'s "[[Walk On By (Burt Bacharach and Hal David song)|Walk On By]]".

content:
==Rationale for use on wikipedia in the article [[Maurice Nicoll]]== {{Navbox |name = Filmr |title = [[Wikipedia:Non-free content|Non-free biography-related media rationale]] |above = '''Rationale for fair use in''' '''''[[Maurice Nicoll]]''''' |group1 = Description: |list1 =
Image of the deceased spiritual teacher and writer [[Maurice Nicoll]]
|group2 = Source: |list2 =
http://www.esotericfreedom.com/images/nicoll.jpg
|group3 = Rationale for use on wikipedia: |list3 =
1.No free equivalent exists that would effectively identify the article's subject - no free images have been allocated for this person.
2.The image does not in any way limit the ability of the copyright owners to market or sell their product.
3.The image is only used once and is rendered in low resolution to avoid piracy.
4.The image has been published outside Wikipedia; see source above.
5.The image meets general Wikipedia content requirements and is encyclopedic.
6.The image meets Wikipedia's media-specific policy.
7.The image is used in the article wiki-linked in the section title.
8.No free images have been allocated for this person
9.The image is needed to identify the person for educational purposes in an encyclopedia entry and significantly improves the quality of the article.
10.The image has a brief description that identifies the image, notes the source, and provides attribution to the copyright holder.
11.A replaceable free image for this person is impossible as he/she is deceased
|group4 = Resolution: |list4 =
The copy is of sufficient resolution for commentary and identification but lower resolution than the original. Copies made from it will be of inferior quality, unsuitable as artwork on pirate versions or other uses that would compete with the commercial purpose of the original artwork.
|group5 = Compatibility with wikipedia?: |list5 =
Use of image in the article complies with [[Wikipedia:Non-free content|Wikipedia non-free content policy]] and [[Fair use|fair use under United States copyright law]] as described above.
}} == Summary == {{Information |Description = Portrait of Nicoll |Source = http://www.esotericfreedom.com/images/nicoll.jpg |Date = 6 April 2008 |Author = uploaded by [[w:User:Marcuslim|Marcus Lim]] at [http://en.wikipedia.org en.wikipedia]. |Portion = Full |Purpose = The image is being used to illustrate an article about the subject of the photograph. |Replaceability = The image is not replaceable, as the subject is deceased. }} == Licensing: == {{Non-free fair use in|Maurice Nicoll}}
